coredata.dc:title: Structural and electrochemical characterization of the Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 amorphous alloy
coredata.dc:creator: Babilas, R.
Bajorek, A.
Hawełek, Ł.
Głuchowski, W.
Simka, W.
Babilas, D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The quaternary Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 metallic glass in the form of ribbons and plates was successfully fabricated by melt-spinning and copper-mold casting. The structure characterization of the alloy in as-cast state was performed by using X-ray diffraction method. The Reverse Monte Carlo modeling was carried out to obtain structural model of the alloy in the form of ribbon. Moreover, the corrosion behavior of glassy plates was studied by electrochemical measurements and immersion tests in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution (pH=5.4) at room temperature. As suspected the lowest corrosion activity of the alloy was observed in 1% NaCl solution. The post-corrosion tests were conducted by scanning electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy to examine the corrosion products and chemical composition of the corroded surfaces. The XPS measurements were used to better understand corrosion behavior of the alloy after immersion during the open-circuit conditions. The corrosion surface products were identified to be CaO, MgO, Mg(OH)2 and CaCO3 components. The ZnO and CuO compounds were formed on the surface of glassy samples.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Ca-based metallic glasses
Corrosion
X-ray diffraction
RMC modeling
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: X-ray diffraction patterns of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy samples in the form of ribbon and plate.
Differential scanning calorimetry pattern of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy plate.
Experimental (solid line) and RMC fitting (dashed line) structure factors for Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glass in the form of ribbon.
Partial pair distribution functions of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy ribbon.
3D structure model of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 metallic glass: (a) simulation box, (b) the layer with a thickness of 0.5nm taken from the (100) plane with the SRO regions circled.
The variation of the E OCP with time for the glassy plates in various NaCl solutions at room temperature.
The polarization curves recorded for the glassy plates in various NaCl solutions at room temperature.
The hydrogen evolution rate of the glassy plates as a function of the immersion time in various NaCl solutions at room temperature.
XPS survey spectrum for Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 amorphous plates after corrosion test in various NaCl solutions (a) and a part of survey spectra in lower binding energy range (b).
XPS narrow scan spectra of C1s (a), O1s (b), Ca2s (c), Mg2p (d), Zn2p (e), Cu2p (f) for Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy plate after corrosion test in 1% NaCl solution.
XPS narrow scan spectra of C1s (a), O1s (b), Ca2s (c), Mg2p (d), Zn2p (e), Cu2p (f) for Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy plate after corrosion test in 2% NaCl solution.
XPS narrow scan spectra of C1s (a), O1s (b), Ca2s (c), Mg2p (d), Zn2p (e), Cu2p (f) for Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy plate after corrosion test in 3.5% NaCl solution.
SEM micrographs and EDS analysis of the surface morphology of studied samples after corrosion tests in 1% (a), 2% (b) and 3.5% (c) NaCl solution at room temperature.
Coordination numbers (N) and inter-atomic distances (r) of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 metallic glass in the form of ribbon.

The results of corrosion resistance investigations of Ca-based glassy plates in NaCl solutions (E OCP - open-circuit potential, E corr - corrosion potential, R p - polarization resistance, j corr - corrosion current density).

head.ce:title: Structural and electrochemical characterization of the Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 amorphous alloy

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The quaternary Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 metallic glass in the form of ribbons and plates was successfully fabricated by melt-spinning and copper-mold casting. The structure characterization of the alloy in as-cast state was performed by using X-ray diffraction method. The Reverse Monte Carlo modeling was carried out to obtain structural model of the alloy in the form of ribbon. Moreover, the corrosion behavior of glassy plates was studied by electrochemical measurements and immersion tests in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution

(pH=5.4) at room temperature. As suspected the lowest corrosion activity of the alloy was observed in 1% NaCl solution. The post-corrosion tests were conducted by scanning electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy to examine the corrosion products and chemical composition of the corroded surfaces. The XPS measurements were used to better understand corrosion behavior of the alloy after immersion during the open-circuit conditions. The corrosion surface products were identified to be CaO, MgO, Mg(OH)2 and CaCO3 components. The ZnO and CuO compounds were formed on the surface of glassy samples.

ce:list-item.ce:para: Ca-based glass was successfully cast in the form of ribbons and plates.
RMC modeling was used to obtain structural model of the alloy.
Corrosion behavior was studied by electrochemical measurements and immersion tests.
Corrosion surface products were identified to be CaO, MgO, Mg(OH)2 and CaCO3.
Hydroxides form hexagonal platelets and calcium carbonates occur as trigonal crystals.

ce:section.ce:para: The quaternary Ca-based bulk metallic glasses are usually presented as an interesting group of metallic amorphous materials due to their specific properties such as low density, high glass-forming ability and rather good mechanical properties [1]. Even though the first Ca-based metallic glasses in alloy systems i.e. Ca-Mg-Cu, Ca-Mg-Ag and Ca-Mg-Ag-Cu were first time prepared by Amiya and Inoue in 2002 [2], there is a still significant interest and development of such light metal-based alloys. Senkov et al. [3,4] produced several Ca-Mg-Zn and Ca-Mg-Zn-Cu bulk metallic glasses by the copper mold casting taking into account some specific criteria described by authors as glass-transition temperature, crystallization temperature, temperature interval of the supercooled region and melting temperature.

Despite of the high glass-forming ability and rather good properties (low density and Young's modulus, high compressive strength) of Ca-based bulk amorphous alloys their potential applications can be limited due to changeable corrosion resistance especially in an aggressive solutions [5]. On the other hand, there is still little known about the atomic structure of light metal-based metallic glasses. Some modeling methods as Monte Carlo techniques are often used to determine the atomic arrangements in non-periodical structure of supercooled materials [6].

Based on mentioned above matters, the two main scientific ways of metallic glass characterization have been considered in the paper: short-range order (SRO) structure and corrosion activity in chloride environments. The local atomic structure of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 amorphous ribbon was studied by using the powder X-ray diffraction and the Reverse Monte Carlo method. Owing to the different application of the alloy, a corrosion investigation should be performed in the related environment. The 3.5% NaCl is the typical salt concentration in sea water. Moreover, the 3.5% NaCl solution is a common and one of the most corrosive agent. In addition, the main reason of the metals corrosion is chloride ions, which facilitate initiation and propagation of the surface damage. Therefore, in order to determine corrosion behavior of glassy plates in milder corrosive environment such as 1% and 2% NaCl and in more corrosive 3.5% NaCl, immersion tests and electrochemical measurements were also conducted. The chemical analysis of the surface after corrosion tests in selected NaCl solutions were provided by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and microscopic observations.

The studies were performed on Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 (at.%) metallic glass in the form of ribbons and plates. The master ingot was prepared by induction melting of pure elements: Ca (99.9%), Mg (99.9%), Cu (99.99%) and Zn (99.99%) in an argon atmosphere. The prepared ingot was remelted in a quartz crucible and then injected into a copper mold by the pressure casting to fabricate 1mm thick plates [7–9] or on the surface of turning Cu-based wheel to produce ribbons [10–12] with the thickness of 0.05mm.

The amorphous structure of the samples (ribbons and plates) in the as-cast state was preliminary checked by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in the reflection mode using the Co Κα radiation source (wavelength=1.7902Å). The diffraction patterns were recorded by “step-scanning” method in the range from 30° to 70° of 2θ angle. The samples for the diffraction measurements were powdered in an agate mortar. The amorphous structure was also confirmed by using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) at a constant heating rate of 20K/min under the argon atmosphere. The DSC method allowed to determine the crystallization temperature and glass-stability of the samples.

Powder X-ray diffraction data were recorded by a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer. The diffractometer was equipped with the Mo Kα radiation source (wavelength=0.7107Å) and the graphite monochromator on the diffracted beam. Data were collected over the 2θ range of 3–160°, with the step size of 0.02° and duration of 40s per step. To calculate the structure factor S(Q) the proper normalization of the recorded data was performed by use of the Rigaku PDXL 2 analysis package. Then, the structure factor was calculated via the PDFgetX3 package [13]. For the further S(Q) analysis the data up to maximum scattering vector Q max =10Å−1 was selected, therefore the real space resolution was limited to 0.31Å.

The scattering vector Q is defined as the difference between the wave vectors, each with the magnitude 2π/λ, in the directions of the incident and scattered beam. The scattering data were represented by the structure factor S(Q) [14]:
(1)
S
Q

I

where < f 2 >=∑ i =1

i and I(Q) indicates the corrected and normalized intensity, c
i is the atomic concentration of the i-th element, f
i is the atomic scattering factor of the i-th kind element and n is the number of the atomic species.

The Reverse Monte Carlo (RMC) calculations were carried out through fitting to the X-ray S(Q)-1 function using RMC_POT software package [15]. A set of 8000 atoms in relevant proportions, randomly distributed in a cube box of 62Å in length, was used as a starting configuration of studied amorphous structure. The number atomic density ρ =0.033489Å−3 was calculated from the chemical composition of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5. It is the concentration of atoms or molecules per unit volume, when the macroscopic density is given, it can be determined as a ratio of physical density and Avogadro's number divided by molecular weight. The macroscopic density was evaluated as 2.45g/cm3 using Archimedes method.

The following cut-off distances were determined throughout the simulation runs: Ca-Ca, 3.8Å; Ca-Mg, 3.5Å; Ca-Cu, 3.2Å; Ca-Zn, 3.2Å; Mg-Mg, 3.0Å; Mg-Cu, 2.8Å; Mg-Zn, 2.8Å; Cu-Cu, 2.4Å; Cu-Zn, 2.5Å; and Zn-Zn, 2.6Å. The data standard deviation was set to 0.01. The cut-offs are minimum interatomic distances, also called as fixed neighbour constraints.

The partial pair distribution functions were obtained from the final RMC model according to [16]:
(2)
g ij RMC
r
=
n ij

4 π
r 2
Δ r
ρ j
where n
j (r) is the number of atoms of type j at a distance between r and r +Δr from a central atom of type i and ρ j is the number density of atoms of the type j.

The discrepancy factor χ2 of calculated and experimental data in RMC simulation was determined [15]:
(3)
χ 2

where k is going through the points of the data set.

The corrosion behavior of the samples in the as-cast state was studied by immersion tests and electrochemical measurements. Due to small thickness of ribbons and high corrosion activity of Ca-based alloy, bulk samples in the form of plates were used. The immersion tests in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution (pH=5.4) at room temperature were conducted to determine an amount of evolved hydrogen using the experimental station described by Atrens et al. [17–19]. The immersion time was 7h.

The electrochemical investigations were conducted in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solutions at room temperature. Following materials were used as electrodes: a sample – working electrode, a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) with a Haber-Luggin capillary – reference electrode and a platinium mesh – counter electrode. The measurements were conducted using a PARSTAT 4000 potentiostat.

The open-circuit potential (E OCP) was measured for 60min from a near-steady-state corrosion potential after a period of stabilization. The evaluation of potentiodynamic polarization curves in the E OCP range from−250mV to+250mV (dE/dt =1mV/s) were collected to determine corrosion potential (E corr), corrosion current density (j corr) and polarization resistance (R
p ) according to Stern-Geary method.

XPS measurements of samples after open-circuit potential tests were conducted in PHI 5700/660 Physical Electronics spectrometer under the high vacuum of 10−10 Torr. The monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6eV) X-ray radiation was used. Before XPS measurements samples were kept under vacuum of 10−9 Torr for 5days. The depth profile analysis was performed using cyclic ion etching (sputtering) with Ar+ beam of 4kV. Each sputtering cycle lasted 15min and afterwards the core level spectra were collected. The whole procedure was repeated through nearly 24h measurement. All the performed spectra were determined relative to the C1s peak, which was used as a reference for charge correction. The data analysis was made by using MultiPak 9.2 software. The survey spectra were collected with the pass energy 187.85eV. Furthermore, all the core level lines were measured with the pass energy 23.50eV and the resolution 0.1eV.
The surface morphology and chemical analysis of glassy plates after corrosion tests were conducted using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS).

The conventional X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that the examined as-cast samples in the form of ribbon and plate were amorphous. The diffraction pattern shows the broad diffraction halo centered at about 37° in 2θ range (Fig. 1 ). The indicted result is typical for an amorphous structure of metallic glasses. The amorphous structure verification by the XRD method enabled further structural measurements and simulations of glassy ribbons.
The corresponding DSC curve with crystallization and glass-transition effects was presented in Fig. 2 . The exothermic peak allowed to determine the onset

(T x =432K) and peak crystallization (T p =441K) temperatures. The DSC trace also contained the endothermic effect corresponds to the glass-transition temperature (T g =406K). The supercooled liquid region ΔT x (T x−
T g) is 26K. The achieved ΔT x is similar to result obtained by Amiya and Inoue [2] who examined the glass-forming ability for Ca81−xMg19Cux alloy series. The ΔT x was determined to be 25K for the 19% Cu metallic glass.

The S(Q)-1 function obtained from powder X-ray diffraction investigations and calculated from the RMC simulation are shown in Fig. 3 . It should be noticed that a quite good agreement between experimental and simulated functions for Q vector in the range of

1–10Å−1 is observed. The results of RMC modeling allow to describe atomic structure of studied ribbon in the short-range order (SRO). The discrepancy factor (χ2) to characterize the goodness of the fit was calculated as 15.8.

The partial pair distribution functions (PDFs) calculated from the fitted RMC model are shown in Fig. 4 . Moreover, the partial PDFs were used to determine the inter-atomic distance of selected atoms. Peak values of Ca-Ca, Ca-Mg, Ca-Cu, Ca-Zn, Mg-Mg, Mg-Cu, Mg-Zn, Cu-Cu, Cu-Zn and Zn-Zn partial PDFs are determined at 3.83, 3.54, 3.25, 3.26, 3.05, 2.85, 2.86, 2.46, 2.55 and 2.65Å, respectively. The calculated inter-atomic distances of Ca-centered atomic pairs show good agreement with results (Ca-Ca 3.8Å, Mg-Ca 3.6Å, Cu-Ca 3.0Å, Cu-Mg 2.7Å, Cu-Cu 2.5Å) obtained by Barney et al. [20] for Ca-Mg-Cu glassy alloys. Moreover, Senkov et al. [1] reported the atomic distances between Ca-Ca (3.94Å), Ca-Mg (3.57Å), Ca-Cu (3.25Å), Mg-Mg (3.20Å) and Mg-Cu (2.88Å) elements calculated for Ca-based glassy alloys.

Table 1 gives average coordination numbers (N), which are the numbers of atoms that are in the nearest-neighbour shell of Ca atom for selected atomic pairs. Theirs inter-atomic distances were determined from peaks of the partial PDFs. The calculated coordination numbers are very similar to values (N Ca-Ca =7.44, N Ca-Mg =2.65) reported by Ju et al. [21] for ternary Ca50Zn30Mg20 metallic glass. Slight differences between values of N calculated by authors of this paper and the coordination numbers reported by Ju et al. are probably due to different chemical composition of studied alloy. Moreover, atoms of Cu and Zn are practically the same from the point of X-ray diffraction. In other words, X-ray diffraction can hardly distinguish individual atomic pairs of Cu-Cu, Cu-Zn and Zn-Zn or Ca-Zn and Ca-Cu as well as between Mg-Zn and Mg-Cu.

Fig. 5a shows the 3D simulation box of 8000 atoms collected from the RMC calculations. The distribution of atoms in the box is not homogeneous. We can notice that atoms segregate and form local ordering areas. These areas can be named as short-range ordering (SRO) regions. The SRO areas are also presented in an atomic layer of 0.5nm in thickness, which was extracted from the simulation box (Fig. 5b). The selected SRO regions of atoms in the 2D view form pentagon (Fig. 5b - 1,2), hexagon (Fig. 5b - 3) and heptagon (Fig. 5b - 4). The indicated plane figures can be assumed as a representation of atomic clusters. It is also known that the SRO regions existing in amorphous structure are also able to grow up directly as the heterogeneous nuclei upon crystallization. Therefore, the identification of SRO areas should be expected as easy ways of transformation to nanocrystals after thermal activation [9].

The results of the open-circuit potential (E OCP) variation with time recorded for the plates in as-cast state immersed in various NaCl solutions are presented in Fig. 6 . The E OCP of the sample immersed in 1% NaCl showed higher value than open circuit potential of the plate examined in 3.5% NaCl solution. The obtained results indicated lower corrosion activity of the glassy sample immersed in 1% NaCl solution in comparison with specimens studied in NaCl with higher concentration. The final values of the E OCP for the studied samples after 60min of immersion were −1236, −1278 and −1303mV vs. SCE after immersion tests in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution, adequately. It was noted that, the corrosion activity of tested alloys depends on the electrolyte concentration. In this work, the corrosion behavior investigations were conducted in less corrosive environment such as 1% NaCl, as well as in strong corrosive solution as 3.5% NaCl. Therefore, in the case of corrosion investigation in 1% NaCl the E OCP of the sample immersed in 1% NaCl showed higher value than open circuit potential of the sample examined in 3.5% NaCl solution (Fig. 6.). Moreover the characteristic of E OCP (t) curve for specimen immersed in 1% NaCl was stable during the all time of test. It indicates that glassy plate was more stable in that corrosive agent in comparison to samples immersed in 2% and 3.5% NaCl. It was also noted, that the E OCP for samples immersed in 2% and 3.5% NaCl increases within the first 200s of test. It can be explained by the worse corrosion resistance in that environment, as well as the corrosion products formation on the specimens' surface. In addition, it can be clearly seen from Fig. 6 that after 200s of test the E OCP - time curves for samples immersed in 2% and 3.5% NaCl were more stable due to the production a protective layer, consisted of calcium and magnesium oxide and hydroxide.
The potentiodynamic polarization curves recorded for the glassy plates after electrochemical measurements in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution are presented in

Fig. 7 . Additionally, the open-circuit potential (E OCP), corrosion current density (j corr), corrosion potential (E corr) and polarization resistance (R p) are listed in Table 2 . The corrosion potential (E corr) of the sample immersed in 1% NaCl solution was −1235mV vs. SCE, corrosion current (j corr) density was 105μA/cm2 and the polarization resistance (R p) was 87.45Ωcm2. In comparison, the corrosion parameters for the same sample tested in 3.5% NaCl solution are found to get worse results. The corrosion potential was −1306mV vs. SCE, the corrosion current density increased to 481μA/cm2 and the polarization resistance decreased to
20.03Ωcm2. The low polarization resistance (R p) and also a high corrosion current density (j corr) of the samples immersed in 2 and 3.5% NaCl indicate that these specimens exhibit
worse corrosion resistance in used corrosion environments.

It should be noticed that corrosion activity of crystalline and glassy light metal-based alloys depends on the electrolyte pH, concentration, as well as kind of the presented anions. Particularly, in acidic medium the corrosion stability of MgCa-based alloys often is worse [22]. Therefore, in this work the pH of examined corrosion solutions was also measured. It was noted that the pH of 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solutions was equalled to 5.4. Based on the electrochemical results, we can state that the acidic environment of examined solution

(pH=5.4), as well as the increase of NaCl concentration caused the increase of corrosion rate of tested Ca-based alloys. For example, the Mg and Mg-based alloys in aqueous solutions formed on their surface protective layer consisted of magnesium oxide and hydroxide. Nevertheless, in chloride ions environment the stability of above mentioned protective layer was poor [23]. High chloride ions concentration provides to transformation Mg(OH)2 to MgCl2. That reaction allows to dissolution of CaMg-based alloys [24]. However, in basic medium (pH=13) e.g. Mg65Cu25Y10, Mg50Ni30Y20 and Mg63Ni30Y7 alloys exhibit better corrosion resistance [22]. Moreover, Dahlam et al. [25] stated that the Ca55Mg18Zn11Cu16 metallic glass was rather corrosion resistant in an aqueous environment.

In chloride solutions calcium and magnesium dissolve, produce hydroxides and evolving hydrogen (H2) [26]. The overall reactions can be described as bellow:
(4)
Ca + 2
H 2
O → Ca
OH
2
+
H 2
(5)
Mg + 2
H 2
O → Mg
OH
2
+
H 2
Fig. 8 shows the hydrogen evolution volume in various NaCl solutions. Studied plates in as-cast state exhibited significant increase of hydrogen evolution volumes as

a function of NaCl concentration. The hydrogen evolution rates of examined plates are 1.5, 6.2 and 13.1ml/cm2 after 7h of immersion tests in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution, respectively. In general, the results of hydrogen evolution tests and electrochemical examinations confirm the lower corrosion resistance and higher activity of studied alloy examined in solutions with higher NaCl concentration.

It is obviously assumed that corrosion resistance of amorphous materials is better than crystalline alloys with the same chemical composition. This advantage can be achieved due to homogeneous microstructure, reduction of impurities and formation of glassy oxide films [22]. Based on these information, the corrosion resistance of metallic glasses should be analyzed taking into account the short-range ordering and formation of atomic clusters. In this paper the RMC calculations were used to describe a local atomic structure of Ca-based glass. Based on result that a distribution of atoms in the RMC simulation box is not homogeneous, we can state that local ordering of atoms (atomic clusters) probably decided on corrosion behavior of the glasses.

Fig. 9a presents the XPS survey spectra for samples of Ca50Mg20Zn5Cu25 alloy with different surface treatments (immersion in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution). The characteristic peaks correspond to chemical species were described. Moreover, Fig. 9b represents a part of survey spectra in lower binding energy range.

The analysis of individual core level lines upon sputtering for the sample treated by 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution shows various behavior of each elements (Figs. 10,11,12
). The C1s line is typical for carbon acumulated on the sample surface (BE=284.8eV) and its intensity is reduced during several first stages of ion etching. The low-intensity line at the higher binding energy (BE≈290.4eV) can be ascribed to various carbonates, mostly to Na2CO3 (Figs. 10a,11a,12a). The peak height can be attributed to difference in the quantity of carbonates.

The oxygen line O1s in 1% and 3.5% NaCl samples ion etching process the line becomes broader indicating the presence of at least two components (Figs. 10b,12b), which can be mostly related to overlapped MgO (BE=531.5eV, 532.2eV) and CaO (BE=531.3eV, 532.2eV) states. Moreover, the presence of Mg(OH)2 (BE=530.9eV) and Cu(OH)2 (BE=531.2eV) compounds can be also considered (Fig. 10b). For 2% NaCl sample the O1s line before ion cleaning is rather typical for Na2CO3 states (BE≈531.6eV). During sputtering process it becomes broad and is clearly splitted into two peaks. The first one is around BE≈531.7eV, the second around BE≈534.5eV and can be related to CaCO3, CaO and MgO, adequately. The part of the O1s broad peak at lower BE dominates after several runs of sputtering (Fig. 11b).

For depth profile analysis the Ca2s (BE≈440eV) line was used. Usually, the Ca2p line has larger intensity, but in this case, it is overlapper with Mg KLL Auger lines and therefore is not perfectly suitable for this kind of analysis. The Ca2s single core level line in all tested specimens is typical for CaO component (Figs. 10c,11c,12c).

The Mg2p line presented as one common spectra with Ca3s line exhibits several elements dependent on the sputtering stage (Figs. 10d,11d,12d). Initially, we can observe mostly MgO (BE=50.2eV) component with a slight broadening after fifth stage of ion cleaning related to Mg(OH)2 (BE=49.8eV). As one may see for 2% NaCl sample the Ca3 line (BE≈44.8eV) shows a relatively largne intensity comparing to Mg2p, which is in accordance to larger amount of CaCO3.

The Zn2p line is very narrow and is composed of two lines Zn2p3/2 (BE≈1022.1±0.7eV) and Zn2p1/2 (BE≈1045.2±0.7eV) associated with ZnO having a spin-orbit splitting of ΔE≈23eV (Figs. 10e,11e,12e). For the 2% NaCl sample the intensity of Zn2p lines is significantly lower than for two other specimens.

The Cu2p lines (Figs. 10f,11f,12f) indicates LS splitting into 2p3/2 (BE≈953.2±0.1eV) and 2p1/2 (BE≈933.6±0.2eV) with L-S splitting of about ΔE≈19.7±0.2eV. Both Cu2p states can be rather assigned as CuO. Furthermore, for 2% NaCl sample one may notice weak satellites structure between 943÷945eV typical for CuO states.

The surface morphology of the glassy plates after electrochemical tests in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution (pH=5.4) is presented in Fig. 13 . The microscopic observations revealed the typical surface morphology with some corrosion products and pits. It was found that the surface of Ca50Mg20Cu25Zn5 glassy alloy after electrochemical test was covered by a thick corrosion products layer containing calcium and magnesium hydroxide/oxide film. As Henrist et al. [27] revealed, magnesium hydroxides form hexagonal platelets, which are characteristic to their crystal structures (Fig. 13a - A). When the concentration of magnesium and calcium hydroxides increases, the globular structure can be observed and large aggregates of spherical units are formed [27,28]. Therefore, the most outspread surface morphology was observed when the examined sample was exposed to 3.5% NaCl (Fig. 13c). In other words, the surface of samples immersed in 1% NaCl solution contains hexagonal platelets (Fig. 13a - A), but also calcium carbonates can be observed as trigonal-rhombohedral crystals (Fig. 13a - B). Small NaCl crystals (Fig. 13a - C) as remains from sodium chloride solution after corrosion tests can be also indicated. Moreover, the increase of NaCl concentration caused the increase of corrosion products formation and their globular structure was observed (Fig. 13b,c).

The EDS analysis exhibited the presence of alloying elements as Ca, Mg, Cu, Zn and additionally O and C on the sample surface. The presence of high oxygen concentration determined by the EDS analysis (the ratio of Ca/O=0.25) probably suggests that oxides and hydroxides can be formed on the surface of tested sample after corrosion measurements. In comparison, Morrison et al. [29] also detected the high oxygen concentration (59at.%) on regions from the cracked surfaces of Ca-Mg-Zn metallic glass after cyclic-anodic-polarization tests in 0.05M Na2SO4 electrolyte.

The diffraction patterns of the studied ribbons and plates of Ca50Mg20Zn5Cu25 alloy showed the broad diffraction halo typical for the amorphous structure. The Reverse Monte Carlo modeling allowed to propose average coordination numbers, which are the number of atoms in the nearest-neighbour shell of Ca atom for selected atomic pairs. Theirs inter-atomic distances were determined from peaks of the partial PDFs. The corrosion behavior of studied alloy was determined by immersion tests and electrochemical measurements in 1, 2 and 3.5% NaCl solution. As suspected the samples examined in 1% NaCl solution exhibited lower corrosion activity than the specimens tested in 2 and 3.5% NaCl environment. The results of immersion tests are in good agreement with electrochemical results and confirm also the lower corrosion resistance tendency as a function of higher NaCl concentration. In acidic environment (pH=5.4) the surface protective layer consisted of calcium/magnesium oxides and hydroxides formed on glassy alloy are not stable. The presence of high oxygen concentration (57.3at.% for samples tested in 3.5% NaCl) determined by the EDS analysis suggests that oxides and hydroxides can be formed on the surface of studied samples after corrosion measurements. The XPS measurements confirmed a formation of CaO, MgO and Mg(OH)2 components. The XPS results also indicated that ZnO and CuO compounds can be formed on the surface of the glassy samples, but without improving the corrosion potential and corrosion current density in NaCl solutions. In order to obtain more precise information about an impact of structure of the studied metallic glass on corrosion behavior a more detailed analysis including a medium range ordering of atoms is necessary.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The work was supported by the Rector's grant in the field of research and development, Silesian University of Technology, no.: 10/010/RGJ17/0142 and partially supported by National Science Centre under research project no.: 2011/03/D/ST8/04138.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Underneath the Bragg peaks: structural analysis of complex materials
Corrosion behaviour of magnesium (Mg)-based bulk metallic glasses
